title: HOW MUCH TO DEREVERBERATE? LOW-LATENCY SINGLE-CHANNEL SPEECH ENHANCEMENT IN DISTANT MICROPHONE SCENARIOS
author: Satvik Venkatesh (L-Acoustics), Philip Coleman (L-Acoustics), Arthur Benilov (L-Acoustics), Simon Brown (L-Acoustics), Selim Sheta (L-Acoustics), Frederic Roskam (L-Acoustics), ...
relevance_why: The study's focus on speech enhancement techniques, particularly dereverberation for distant microphone scenarios, aligns closely with my research interest in audio restoration and enhancement.
background: This paper investigates techniques for enhancing speech quality and intelligibility captured via distant microphones in large reverberant environments like conference rooms and theaters.
contribution: This paper introduces a method for real-time single-channel speech enhancement in distant microphone settings, achieving significant improvements in intelligibility and quality compared to traditional methods.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods typically address small-room settings or short microphone distances, leading to suboptimal performance in larger spaces.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work incorporates volume-based reverberation time sampling and adaptive impulse response shaping, enabling effective dereverberation in challenging environments.

key_innovation: It uniquely simulates room acoustics by considering room volume and reverberation time to generate more realistic training data for speech enhancement models.
real_world_impact: The methods proposed have practical applications in environments like lectures and performances, enhancing audience experience by improving speech clarity and reducing background noise effects.
limitations: The paper does not explicitly mention any limitations but may face challenges in generalizing to various acoustic environments beyond those studied.

new_terms.dereverberation: **Dereverberation** refers to the process of reducing reverberation, or the persistence of sound in an environment, to improve speech clarity.
new_terms.reverberation time (T60): **Reverberation time (T60)** is the time it takes for a sound to decay by 60 dB in a space, influencing how echo and clarity are perceived.
